docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Secretary of State may refuse to grant passports to United States citizens for travel to Cuba....
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Secretary of State may refuse to grant passports to United States citizens for travel to Cuba.
docs.abstract: US Sup Ct, 6-3, upholds State Dept power to refuse to grant passports for travel to Cuba, L Zemel case; decision upholds dept right to designate areas to which citizens may not travel without its permission, distinguishes situation from earlier cases in which it invalidated dept efforts to deny passports

headline.main: HIGH COURT BACKS CUBA TRAVEL BAN; Says State Department Can Limit Journeying Abroad

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The State Department has advised inquiring Representatives and Senators on Capitol Hill that it is opposed to granting them passports to visit Communist China....
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The State Department has advised inquiring Representatives and Senators on Capitol Hill that it is opposed to granting them passports to visit Communist China.
docs.abstract: J Reston repts State Dept opposes granting passports for travel to Communist China

headline.main: CHINA TRAVEL BAN HITS LEGISLATORS; State Department Opposes Giving Passports -- Dispute Is Expected to Grow

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Hungary's officials in Washington may travel freely within a forty-mile radius of the White House under liberalized travel restrictions announced today by the State Department....
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Hungary's officials in Washington may travel freely within a forty-mile radius of the White House under liberalized travel restrictions announced today by the State Department.
docs.abstract: US eases travel curbs on Hungarian officials, Washington, in reciprocity move

headline.main: U. S. EASES TRAVEL BAN; Extends Area Hungarian Envoys May Now Visit

docs.snippet: The United States plans to continue excluding foreigners infected with the AIDS virus at least through July while the Bush Administration tries to settle a dispute on the question among several Federal agencies, Administration officials said tonig...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States plans to continue excluding foreigners infected with the AIDS virus at least through July while the Bush Administration tries to settle a dispute on the question among several Federal agencies, Administration officials said tonight. The officials said Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, would maintain existing restrictions for at least 60 days by reissuing the current list of diseases justifying the exclusion of aliens from the United States.

headline.main: Ban on Aliens With AIDS to Continue for Now

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Soviet proposal for an agreement to ban nuclear testing, announced today, was viewed skeptically by United States officials as another maneuver to obtain an indefinite, uncontrolled moratorium on such tests....

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to give the Government "clear statutory authority" to refuse passports to known Communists and those subject to Communist party discipline, domination or control....

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2--Three San Francisco lawyers are preparing a suit challenging the manner in which immigration officials bar homosexuals from entering the United States....
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2--Three San Francisco lawyers are preparing a suit challenging the manner in which immigration officials bar homosexuals from entering the United States.
docs.abstract: 3 lawyers file suit, Federal District Court, San Francisco, challenging manner in which immigration officials bar homosexuals from entering US; suit stems from recent incident in which Chavez Carrillo was detained by airline security guards in hotel room for 14 hours and then denied legal entry after signing statement saying he was homosexual; Chavez was eventually 'paroled into US' for 2 weeks; provision barring homosexuals was upheld in '67 by US Supreme Court (M)

headline.main: SUIT TO CONTEST U.S. ON HOMOSEXUAL BAN; Lawyers Assail Immigration Office on Methods of Enforcing Law Law Held 'Immune From Attack' Official Revised Procedure
